node.bodyHTML:
Work towards #3347, don't use this yet üòÅ, want to try this out in a nightly release.

Figured out two different possible approaches for using this with multi-stage docker builds. First option is to use 3 stages, where stage one creates a repo skeleton with only yarn.lock + all package.json, stage two does a cached install and build, and stage 3 builds the actual backend image. This method would be required for when the frontend is bundled with the backend.

Second approach would be to just use two stages and never run a full yarn install, but instead only install @backstage/cli globally in the first stage and run the backend:bundle command. This won't be able to build the frontend, but may be a significant shortcut to getting the backend shipped.

node.bodyHTML:
Hey, I just made a Pull Request!

Adds backstage-cli versions:bump and backstage-cli versions:check, which allow users to bump @backstage packages to the latest versions, and remove duplicates.

The bump commands will pull down the latest version of each @backstage package and then run a deduplication. The idea is that this command can be used to easily stay on top of the latest releases without having to manually sift though package.jsons. There's currently no way to select which weekly release of the packages to use, it will always use the latest release. The metadata returned from npm contains enough information about the releases that it should be possible to add that if we want to.

The check command will detect duplicates of the @backstage packages and warn the user. If the --fix flag is provided, it will act like yarn-deduplicate and get rid of any duplicates that can be removed while staying within the requested version range. It will also warn about packages that can't be deduplicated automatically, and exit with an error if any of those packages are known to not function if there are duplicates, such as @backstage/core.

Fixes #3185, although will likely leave this undocumented until after the next release. I did some local verification but want to make sure this works properly with a released version too.

‚úîÔ∏è Checklist

  • A changeset describing the change and affected packages. (more info)
  • Added or updated documentation
  • Tests for new functionality and regression tests for bug fixes
  • Screenshots attached (for UI changes)

node.bodyHTML:
Ok - so two PR's (both merged by me on thursday so made it into the release), had compounding effects and made the latest version of the scaffolder just hang with no way of closing the modal on failure or completion.

This was a combination of this PR:
#2807 - which assumed that you don't want to close the modal whilst the job is rendering, but on complete this modal should close from the parent component.

And this change: https://github.com/backstage/backstage/pull/3351/files#diff-aed9d4af64e330fb10d19149c39b210de26caec0508e2e01a6e14fe597eb19b4R57-R60 which assumes that when a component is created. by the scaffolder there should always be catalog-info.yaml in the repo that is created to add to the catalog. If it isn't there, it post's an error to the errorApi however, the modal never gets unmounted, so you get stuck with the modal and no way to close it because of the previous change.

This PR updates all of the sample templates we have to have the correct file naming, and a bit of documentation suggesting that you should have this file in place.

It also reworks the entire validation flow, so that the modal will give you the ablilty to close when the scaffolder flow is complete, but solve the original requirement that you shouldn't be able to accidentally click off whilst it's working it's magic.

When the scaffolder is complete, you get the To catalog button, and when it fails you get a Close link on the modal.

If at any time, for backwards compaitbility, it's complete but the file is not there and unable to register automatically, you will get an error saying it couldn't do it automatically, as well as the ability to close the modal! üéâ

  • A changeset describing the change and affected packages. (more info)
  • Added or updated documentation
  • Tests for new functionality and regression tests for bug fixes
  • Screenshots attached (for UI changes)
node.title: fix: Sample Templates are broken with latest release

node.bodyHTML:
Hey, I just made a Pull Request!

Some improvements to the CircleCI builds table:

  • The Build column now shows the jobName if the buildName is not present (which can be the case when builds are scheduled)
  • Added a Job column which links to the external job
  • Updated the Source column to show the users avatar and a short hash instead of the full sha. It also has a link to the source control commit
  • Added a Time column which displays the start time and duration (humanized)
  • Added a Workflow column to indicate which workflow the job is from.
  • Some other minor refactoring changes (e.g. removed usage of react FC).

NOTE: Also moved the CircleCI above GH Actions in the CICDSwitcher in the example app. This ensures the CircleCI annotation is used rather then the common github/project-slug key first.

‚úîÔ∏è Checklist

  • A changeset describing the change and affected packages. (more info)
  • Added or updated documentation
  • Tests for new functionality and regression tests for bug fixes
  • Screenshots attached (for UI changes)

node.bodyHTML:
Bumps passport-saml from 1.3.3 to 2.0.2.

Release notes

Sourced from passport-saml's releases.

v2.0.2

Bug Fixes

  • normalize line endings before signature validation (02c6c5a)

v2.0.1

Bug Fixes

  • deprecation notice bug fix privateKey (#492). This was bug was introduced in unrelease v2.0.0.

v2.0.0

(Not published to NPM)

Our test suite passes un-modified with 2.0, but some cases that could possibly be breaking changes for some users are disclamed here. Some changes made over the the last week are also repeated here since most people would not have upgraded to those.

Possibly Breaking Changes

  • Dropped Support for Node 8 (since v1.4.0)

  • Upgraded xml-crypto to 2.0.0 to address vulnerability in that module. This should be backwards compatible unless you were going out of your way to enable HMAC-SHA1.

  • Rewritten in TypeScript. All existing tests pass, but a Babel user ran into a compatibility issue in #475, so this is noted in case there's another case like that.

  • We now follow the best practice of throwing Error objects instead of strings. If your code explicitly expected strings to be thrown, it will need to be updated. (#412)

  • We were using "q" promises internally and now use native promises. There has not been a documented a public promise interface, so this should not be a compatibility issue unless you were accessing the internals. (since 1.5.0)

New Features

  • Better safety due to switching source code to TypeScript.

  • IdP part of SAML spec is now implemented. See (#428)

  • The less confusing privateKey config key name is now preferred over privateCert. privateCert still works, but will likely be deprecated. (#488)

  • validateSignature: Support XML docs that contain multiple signed nodes (#455)

Bug Fixes

... (truncated)

Commits
  • 711956c Release 2.0.2
  • 02f3e09 chore: release-it Github Release support.
  • 0da87a2 chore: bump version in package-lock.json
  • dc1f2f0 deps: add release-it dev dep
  • 02c6c5a normalize line endings before signature validation
  • b349e4b v2.0.1
  • c2f32c6 Add deprecation notice for privateCert; fix bug (#492)
  • be111f3 v2.0.0
  • 13b491c add multiSamlStrategy.d.ts to the package
  • b2d5b0b add multiSamlStrategy.d.ts to exclude for typescript
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view

"The table is nice and clean, but it sort of makes us do some gymnastics to make the search results conform to the columns.

I like the idea of coming in with an opinionated view of a "search result" model (e.g. title, summary, link, type, owner, etc.), and mapping entities (maybe other things in the future) to match that model."

Would love to collect your ideas and suggestions here so please comment below!
node.title: [Search] Second iteration of search result component

node.bodyHTML:
On the search page we do have two filter types at the moment. A selection of Kinds and checkboxes of lifecycles. The data for this is currently just hard coded in the Filters component.

The different kinds and lifecycles can look different depending on what entities that exist, therefore it would be nice to dynamically load all the filter options that exist for all your entities.

For example, "The kind filter doesn't include User and Group, though they are in the table listing for me." and "e.g., if there are no APIs registered, than we shouldn't need to filter by them."

  • Investigate if there is any existing api for this, maybe in the catalog client.
  • Replace the hard coded filters with dynamically loaded data.
node.title: [Search] Dynamically load filter options

node.bodyHTML: The search results gets listed in a Table view, this table view gives you component id, description, owner, kind and lifecycle. Currently you are not able to navigate to the result you find, therefore we would like to wrap the component id in a Link component. Clicking on the Link should take you to the entity page for that specific result.
node.title: [Search] Links to entity page for each search result

node.bodyHTML:
Feature Suggestion

Right now the only simply way to deploy a production version of the backend is by using the backend:build-image command. It creates a temporary folder outside of the repo and copies over the distribution versions of each backend package in the monorepo and then runs the Docker build within that package. This ensures that the resulting backend image only contains backend dependencies and built code. It also avoid installation of development dependencies.

Because the backend:build-image command is operating both on the host machine and docker, it can't be used inside a docker build itself, or in build environments that run exclusively in docker containers and don't support docker in docker. There is a lower-level build-workspace command that can be used to replicate this setup, but the backend:build-image command also adds proper docker build caching of yarn install as well as automatic detection and building of all dependencies of the backend within the monorepo, both which are very tedious and verbose to replicate manually within a Dockerfile.

We should aim to restructure the backend production build process to preferably generate usable build output isolated to just the dist/ dir. It should also allow for yarn install --production to be run afterwards, with installation limited to only the involved packages.

Possible Implementation

Possibly something similar to how the current build-workspace and backend:build-image commands work, but move the output to a dist/ dir instead? It's tricky because we want to ensure that the node_modules structure is the same as during development.

Context

This is brought up daily in Discord #support üòÖ
node.title: Add a backend:bundle command to the CLI

node.bodyHTML:
We have created a GitHub scraping service that creates a Location resource based on all GitHub repositories in an organisation (closed source for now).
The scraper will detect if a repository contains documentation, API specifications etc. and set annotations on the generated Component resources accordingly while also generating eg API resources.

With this approach we don't need the write functionality of the service catalog, ie. Create component.
Currently it's still there, but on every restart of backstage we reset the catalog to the generated resources and the changes are lost.

Feature Suggestion

Add a configuration option for making the catalog read-only.
When enabled all mutating functionality should be disabled, routes not registered, eg. /create and the backend should refuse write operations.

Possible Implementation

Maybe just something in app-config.yaml:

catalog:
  mode: readonly

In the components we should then have a simple way of detecting this to conditionally render them.

Context

We use a GitOps approach in our infrastructure meaning that all resources for workloads are stored in Git.
We would like to keep this in the same pattern as this is what developers are used to.

Generated Location, Component and API resources:

apiVersion: backstage.io/v1alpha1
kind: Location
metadata:
  name: lunar-components
spec:
  type: url
  targets:
    - https://github.com/lunarway/backstage-resources/blob/master/resources/components/service.component.yaml
    - https://github.com/lunarway/backstage-resources/blob/master/resources/components/service.api.yaml
---
apiVersion: backstage.io/v1alpha1
kind: Component
metadata:
  name: service
  description: 'A description'
  annotations:
    backstage.io/managed-by-location: 'github:https://github.com/lunarway/service.git'
    jenkins.io/github-folder: 'lunarway/service/master'
    github.com/project-slug: 'lunarway/service'
spec:
  type: service
  lifecycle: dev
  owner: squad
  implementsApis:
    - service-http
---
apiVersion: backstage.io/v1alpha1
kind: API
metadata:
  name: service-http
  description: API for service.
spec:
  type: openapi
  lifecycle: dev
  owner: squad
  definition: |
    // omitted
node.title: [ServiceCatalog] Read only mode

node.bodyHTML:
Status: Open for comments

Need

At Spotify, we have shared infrastructure services that are layered on top of cloud services. For example, a build system that reads Pub/Sub messages, executes builds on a VM, and saves the results in BigQuery. The costs for this infrastructure can be allocated to teams using it based on labels, but it would be confusing to present costs in terms of the underlying cloud products; the costs can be grouped instead by the triggering entity.

So far, we've used the notion of Product in Cost Insights loosely and had shared services represented as their own product panel. This worked fine so far, but #3268 introduced SKU breakdowns for products which leaks the abstraction a bit. For shared services, there's a different breakdown hierarchy:

Cloud product
Product > Entity > SKU

Shared service
Service > Entity > Product > SKU

The cloud product breakdown for a shared service is useful to the entity owners since there are configuration options that can control the product usage - for example, whether the data should be stored in BigQuery or GCS, and for how long.

For our current internal examples, the final level of SKU for shared services is not critical and would not provide meaningful value to engineers. The shared service team manages their own infrastructure, so entity owners using the infrastructure have little control or desire to inspect this deep into the service.

Proposal

Ignoring the SKU-level breakdown of a shared service, the level of hierarchy for the shared service is identical to a cloud product. Therefore, we could re-use the same SKU breakdown concept from #3268 for a product-level breakdown of shared services.

The SKU term is hard-coded right now in ProductInsightsChart, the Entity type in Cost Insights could have an entitiesLabel field alongside the entities array. This could be set to "SKU", "Product", etc. as appropriate. I think this would be preferable to each child entity having a label, since you could have a strange situation where an array of entities have differing labels.

Alternatives

Alternatively, the entity bar charts could use stacked bars to break down the shared service by product and still support the SKU-level breakdown via #3268:

This falls down a bit when the breakdown exceeds a handful of products, which is why we rejected the approach for SKU breakdowns. Some entities can result in many SKUs, and while a shared service would be less likely to suffer from this, it may still be messy with 4+ products.

The tooltip when mousing over this would need to show a row for each product with columns for the start/end periods. Something akin to this mockup from when we considered a similar approach for the SKU breakdown:

This introduces some confusing interaction where different breakdowns appear both on hover and on click.

Risks

The advantage of the alternative approach is that SKU-level breakdown can still be supported for shared services. However, this could be overcome in a different way if desired in the original approach. Technically, multiple levels of breakdown are possible with the data model. This is not currently UI-supported, but it could be someday.

Additionally, one could argue that shared services should be represented differently in the data model rather than (ab)using the Product type. We may want to revisit this if our needs around shared services expand in Cost Insights.
node.title: [RFC] Shared service breakdowns in Cost Insights

node.bodyHTML:
Feature Suggestion

#3264 added support for configuration schema along with mostly complete schemas for @backstage/cli, @backstage/core, and @backstage/backend-common. In addition the minimal required schema was also added for all frontend plugins to receive their required config.

We should fill the schema with descriptions and examples for the rest of all possible config values. The following packages are known to either be completely or partially missing config schema:

  • packages/backend-common (.backend.{database,cors,csp})
  • plugins/auth-backend
  • plugins/catalog-backend
  • plugins/cost-insights
  • plugins/kubernetes-backend
  • plugins/proxy-backend
  • plugins/scaffolder-backend
  • plugins/techdocs
  • plugins/techdocs-backend
  • plugins/sentry
  • plugins/rollbar-backend (#3404)
  • plugins/sonarqube (#3378)

Possible Implementation

It's usually easiest to define schema using the .d.ts approach. To discover required schema it's best to browse the existing config YAMLs as well as search for usages for the config API within the packages.

Context

#2854 #3367 #3366
node.title: Fill out missing or incomplete configuration schema

node.bodyHTML:
Feature Suggestion

#3264 added support for configuration schema, but does not make the entire fully stitched schema available for editor integration. Having this schema available in editors would make it much nicer to edit app-config.yaml files and the like, as it would provide autocompletion and documentation popups.

Possible Implementation

We could provide a command from the cli that allows you to save the entire stitched schema to a file, something like backstage-cli config:generate-schema --output .config-schema.local.yaml. This could then be added as a "postinstall" step and the schema file itself could be registered in the editor to at least handle app-config*.yaml files.

Another option would be a more direct editor integration like a VSCode extension that is able to with the @backstage/config-loader package to load in the schema behind the scenes. This has the benefit of not adding additional processes and files to the repo, but is a bit more of a maintenance burden and perhaps something that anyone from the community could pick up separately.

Context

#2854
node.title: Provide autocompletion and schema checks when editing configuraiton files

node.bodyHTML:
Feature Suggestion

#3264 added support for configuration schema, but there is not yet a way to view the schema in a nice documentation format. We should add that! üòÅ

Possible Implementation

Since schemas are stitched together based on the dependencies of each app, it's tricky to provide one documentation that fits everyone. I'm thinking that godoc is something we can model the solution after. It provides a CLI that serves content locally based on local packages, but also has a hosted service that provides documentation for all community packages. Both of those could be desirable but either way we'd start be shipping the CLI üòÅ

For documentation generation based on JSON Schema there are quite a lot of options. It's ofc best if we're able to stick to node modules though, or we'd likely want to provide a publicly hosted service that does the conversion. One option is https://github.com/adobe/jsonschema2md but there seems to be many more, haven't dug deep into options here so suggestions are welcome! A fallback would ofc be to create our own as well, but that would be nice to avoid

Context

#2854
node.title: Configuration documentation generation

node.bodyHTML:
Status: Open for comments

Need

An often requested feature from Spotify engineers is for products to be stacked according to greatest cost.

Proposal

Stack rank and label products according to greatest cost over a given period.

Alternatives

There are multiple possible implementations of the stack rank feature

Stack Rank Product Panels

Stack rank product panels over a default period. Preserve initial sort order.

This approach is the simplest but potentially misleading. In order for stack rank to be significant, products should be compared according to the same set of criteria. If a user were to toggle a period for an individual product, but the product panels remained in original sort order, it would visually imply that product costs are comparable across disparate periods.

Global Period Selection

Add a page-level, or panel-level selection that toggles the period selections for each product panel to allow users to compare product costs over the same periods. Selections would refetch product data for each panel and resort product panels. Individual period selections would not trigger a resort.

Separate Stack Rank Component

A separate stack rank component could be implemented that stack ranked products in a compact display at the top of the page or at the top of the section. The panels themselves would remain in the order according to configuration, not greatest cost.

Risks

The greatest risks associated with this feature are potentially misleading rank results when comparing product costs across disparate periods. Additionally, more global selections can lead to more visual bloat.
node.title: [RFC] Stack Rank Cost Insights Product Panels

node.bodyHTML:
Feature Suggestion

The new Catalog Importer (#3121) opens a pull request to add a catalog-info.yaml file to the repo if none exists already.

Currently, there is no description in the pull request which is opened by the automation. The Pull Request should have a description which explains its purpose. The pull request should be configurable because different organisations will want to explain Backstage differently, depending on their unique context.

Possible Implementation

  • The PR is opened from the frontend of Backstage so whatever configuration is passed in will need to be available there.
  • The description might get a bit long to make sense in the app-config.yaml.

Context

  1. I want to explain to my team why these pull requests are being opened and help people understand the value of Backstage.
  2. I want to be able to look back the pull requests in future and remember, by reading the description, why they were opened.
node.title: Catalog importer should add a configurable description when opening forks

node.bodyHTML:
Feature Suggestion

The Catalog importer can currently only add catalog-info.yaml files into the root of the repos that are being added. Monorepos may need multiple catalog-info.yaml files at different paths.

Possible Implementation

Allow the user to choose (via dropdown) or enter (via basic text input) the path at which they would like the catalog-info.yaml file to appear.
node.title: Catalog importer should support monorepos

node.bodyHTML:
When you use the Unregister Entity button on one of the entities that are registered via the app-config.yaml:

backstage/app-config.yaml

Lines 157 to 175 in 6a6744c

locations:
# Backstage example components
- type: url
target: https://github.com/backstage/backstage/blob/master/packages/catalog-model/examples/all-components.yaml
# Example component for github-actions
- type: url
target: https://github.com/backstage/backstage/blob/master/plugins/github-actions/examples/sample.yaml

target: https://github.com/backstage/backstage/blob/master/plugins/techdocs-backend/examples/documented-component/documented-component.yaml
# Backstage example APIs
- type: url
target: https://github.com/backstage/backstage/blob/master/packages/catalog-model/examples/all-apis.yaml
# Backstage example templates
- type: url
target: https://github.com/backstage/backstage/blob/master/plugins/scaffolder-backend/sample-templates/all-templates.yaml
# Backstage example groups and users
- type: url
target: https://github.com/backstage/backstage/blob/master/packages/catalog-model/examples/acme-corp.yaml

the bootstrap location is removed. In installations with a persistent database, this breaks the as-code registration for the future.

Expected Behavior

  • The bootstrap location should not be deletable
  • Maybe not remove all sibling-entities from this special location

Possible Solution

Different options:

  1. Disable the unregister function for as-code entities
  2. Special code on unregister to not remove the bootstrap location
  3. Always add it on startup, if missing
  4. ‚Ä¶
  5. Replace the bootstrap location with something else.
node.title: Don't remove the bootstrap location on removal of a child-entity

node.bodyHTML:
Status: Open for comments

Continuation from https://github.com/backstage/backstage/pull/3387/files#r528254139

Need

The usage of momentjs should be sunset for a more modern alternative based on the projects own status and suggestions. There should ideally be one standard library that is used in the core packages and plugins for date manipulation beyond what can be easily handled by the JS Date object.

  • Why you shouldn't use Moment.js...
  • More alternatives to Moment.js
  • You don't (may not) need Moment.js

Some common requirements are:

  • Duration / diffs
  • Humanizing relative time & durations (e.g. 2 days ago, about 2 mins)
  • ISO 8601 period support (e.g. P1M, P30D)
  • etc.

Proposal

We should pick a date/time library that can be used consistently across the core packages and plugins. After picking the library, we create and ADR and work towards replacing existing usage of momentjs, etc. to use the new standardized choice. We should also consider creating some standard helper functions for things like duration and relative time, which are very common for CI plugins, etc.

The following are the most likely candidates which cover many of the requirements and have feature rich APIs. Here's a list of relevant notes on these libraries.

This site does a good comparison - https://github.com/you-dont-need/You-Dont-Need-Momentjs

luxon

  • Familiar API to momentjs wrapper object
  • Uses immutable objects
  • No tree shaking
  • Does not support relative time

date-fns

  • Uses JS dates directly (no wrapper objects)
  • Provided as a series of functions that can be composed using FP techniques
  • Supports tree shaking

dayjs

  • Uses a wrapper object similar to momentjs & luxon
  • Small footprint size (2k)
  • Fast
  • No tree shaking support

Alternatives

Are there any alternatives we should consider?

Risks

Continued usage of moment will make it harder to switch to another library in the future. It also will affect front-end bundle sizes as moment is not tree shaking friendly. Not picking a standardized library that supports the common use cases will likely cause multiple libraries to be used over time. This could cause greater bundles in the full front-end build and also require learning multiple libraries.
node.title: [RFC] Standardized Date & Time library

node.bodyHTML:

Error: Module build failed (from /home/aharvey29/github/backstage/node_modules/@sucrase/webpack-loader/dist/index.js):
SyntaxError: Error transforming /home/aharvey29/github/backstage/node_modules/@backstage/plugin-kubernetes-backend/src/service/getKubernetesObjectsForServiceHandler.ts:
Unexpected token (105:10)

and

aharvey@mycomp:~/github/backstage/packages/backend(master)*$ yarn start
yarn run v1.22.1
$ backstage-cli backend:dev
Build succeeded
webpack-internal:///../../node_modules/@backstage/plugin-kubernetes-backend/src/service/getKubernetesObjectsForServiceHandler.ts:1
throw new Error("Module build failed (from /home/aharvey29/github/backstage/node_modules/@sucrase/webpack-loader/dist/index.js):\nSyntaxError: Error transforming /home/aharvey/github/backstage/node_modules/@backstage/plugin-kubernetes-backend/src/service/getKubernetesObjectsForServiceHandler.ts: Unexpected token (105:10)

Is anyone else seeing that? I did a yarn cache clean, a re: yarn install, yarn tsc, yarn build, and all good, but the startup fails. I wonder if it requires a YAML config in alignment or something?

Note this is with the raw mem-based SqlLite database so no catalog entries with k8s annotations that I'm aware of.

Expected Behavior

Current Behavior

Failed backend msg, and backend is not working properly. Catalog is failing to load when using through the front end.

Possible Solution

Steps to Reproduce

  1. Get latest code
  2. Yarn install, yarn tsc, yarn build
  3. yarn start in monorepo home, and then yarn start in packages/backend.
  4. Immediate errors in the backend at startup.

Context

Your Environment

  • Operating System and Version (e.g. Ubuntu 14.04): Windows 10 1909 WSL2
